awd_titl_txt: Exploring how protein conformation influences assembly of transcriptional complexes on snRNA gene promoters
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will provide key insights into the mechanism by which small differences in DNA nucleotide sequence can affect the shape of a flexible DNA-binding protein. Importantly, this change in protein shape leads to a significant difference in biological outcome that is crucial to the correct utilization of genetic information. The project will provide biochemical training for at least three graduate students, six undergraduate students, a high school student, and a postdoctoral fellow. These trainees will contribute to the future of the scientific enterprise by pursuing careers in biotechnology, academia, or related fields. As the majority of these trainees are expected to be from under-represented groups, the project will contribute to the diversity of the scientific workforce. 

Genetic information present in the DNA must be read out within living cells in a very defined and specific manner. The first step in the expression of genetic information involves the synthesis of RNA from the DNA template in a process termed transcription. In higher organisms, transcription is carried out by three different RNA polymerases termed polymerases I, II, and III. Each of these polymerases is involved in RNA synthesis from a distinct set of genes and must be recruited to the DNA promoter usually by distinct sets of sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins. These promoter binding proteins bind to DNA sequences near the transcription start site. The U1 and U6 snRNA genes code for essential small RNA molecules involved in the splicing of messenger RNAs. The promoters of the U1 and U6 genes are very similar to each other, yet contain functionally significant differences. A protein complex, SNAPc (which is uniquely required for snRNA gene transcription), adopts different conformations on fruit fly U1 and U6 gene promoters due to binding to minimally-different DNA sequences. It is hypothesized that these distinct conformations of SNAPc are involved in the recruitment of RNA polymerase II to transcribe the U1 gene but RNA polymerase III to transcribe the U6 gene. The project will investigate how the different conformations of SNAPc lead to differential RNA polymerase recruitment. Protein-DNA interactions will be mapped by site-specific protein-DNA photo-cross-linking combined with site-specific protein cleavage. Protein-protein interactions will be mapped by cross-linking mass spectrometry. Basic biochemical techniques will be employed throughout the project. The knowledge obtained from these experiments will be used to construct molecular models to aid in understanding how RNA polymerase transcription pre-initiation complexes assemble on snRNA promoters.

por.por_cntn:
Successful and correct gene expression is dependent upon the precise assembly of transcription initiation complexes that contain several different proteins. These proteins are called transcription factors, and they bind to each other and to the DNA in a concerted fashion to enable correct gene expression.  In this study, we examined the binding of transcription factors to promoter DNA sequences located upstream of the U6 gene. The U6 promoter DNA contains particular base pair sequences to which specific transcription factors can bind to direct RNA synthesis from the U6 gene. Importantly, accurate transcription of the U6 snRNA gene is essential for the viability of higher organisms, as U6 snRNA is required for splicing the precursors of messenger RNAs.

Experiments funded by this grant provided data that allowed us to propose a model for the initial assembly of a transcription factor complex on the U6 snRNA gene. The U6 model obtained contains three proteins (known as SNAPc, Bdp1, and TBP) bound to the U6 snRNA gene promoter DNA (see accompanying figure). By knowing the configuration of this partial U6 transcription pre-initiation complex, we begin to understand how these proteins are involved in recruiting the enzyme RNA polymerase III to the U6 gene to synthesize U6 snRNA. Future work is needed to compare it to transcription complexes formed on other genes. Of greatest interest, it will be important to compare it to transcription complexes established on the U1 gene, which is transcribed by a different RNA polymerase (RNA polymerase II). Both U6 and U1 genes are initially dependent upon the SNAPc transcription factor to initiate the formation of either RNA polymerase III or RNA polymerase II transcription complexes. The question arises: how is it that the same protein, SNAPc, can exclusively lead to the formation of two different types of transcription complexes (one RNA polymerase III and one RNA polymerase II)? We have postulated that small differences in the U6 and U1 promoter sequences cause SNAPc to adopt slightly different shapes that in turn result in the differential recruitment of either RNA polymerase III or RNA polymerase II transcription factors. To test this hypothesis, it will be important to learn the shape of SNAPc while bound to the U1 promoter, as well as to the U6 promoter, so that the conformation of SNAPc and the transcription complexes that it initiates can be compared under the two different scenarios. This awaits future investigation.

The findings of the project were widely disseminated throughout the scientific community by the publication of 2 papers in refereed journals. Also, results were presented at 3 scientific meetings. Moreover, 2 Ph.D. dissertations and one M.S. thesis were published.

Finally, the funding provided by this grant made possible the training of 7 undergraduates, 2 M.S. students, 2 Ph.D. students, and 1 postdoctoral research fellow. It was a diverse group of students that received training, including Hispanic, Southeast Asian, Korean, and Caucasian.  Essentially all of these trainees currently have careers in academia, the biotech industry, or the health care community. Thus, this grant has augmented the nation's total workforce, as well as the diversity of the workforce, in areas of significant national interest.
